Campus.Review: The weather is never too hot. Even in the summer, 80's is about as high as the temperature goes. In cooler seasons it gets fairly cold at night. By cold, I mean that you may need a hoodie or sweatshirt. There are never temps below freezing. In the winter, there are quite a few rainy days, but there is virtually no rain during other seasons.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Large Screen Macs Everywhere That Dual Boot Windows â€“ And they're all equipped with Visual Studio C++. What more could you want?
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: ...you get here. First off, the WEATHER is FANTASTIC. I have a dozen friends going to schools in the Northeast freezing their asses off while I'm wearing shorts and sandals in January. Secondly, the quarter system rocks, and we are incredibly flexible with classes: three week shopping period, five week withdraw period, and prerequisites are not enforced. And we have (or at least I do) great advisors. Thirdly, the computer science here is the best in the world, so if that's what you're into (or symbolic systems), come here.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Everything you need is on campus-- including a shopping center complete with Sprinkles Cupcakes, PinkBerry, Kate Spade, and Louis Vuitton. Palo Alto is pricey, but there are awesome cafes and restaurants; University Ave is always a lovely trip off campus. Do not expect your typical college town, though, you will not find that in ritzy Palo Alto. San Francisco is about an hour away, and though most students rarely go to the city, it is always an option, especially for upperclassmen. The beach is also not far away for a weekend trip, and in the winter students go up to Tahoe for ski trips.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The campus is just one of the most beautiful there is.  There is a good variety of libraries to study at, the gym is awesome, the tennis courts are many, the dorms are okay, and the classroom buildings are nice.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: One of the (if not THE) most aesthetically pleasing campuses I've been to. Large variety of new and "old" buildings. Facilities are great.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Awful: Everything's Taken by 9Am â€“ Super limited parking. Students who live on campus can buy monthly/yearly permits that cost roughly $25/month to get spaces near the dorms. You still have to circle for 10 minutes to find a spot. There are commuter permits, only for employees who live off campus(especially the med school) and these always seem to be in the prime places. Very limited visitor parking and very pricey ($1.25/hour), and enforced 8am to 4pm M-F. Parking is free on weekends EXCEPT where marked in tiny lettering on signs. Stanford must get thousands of dollars every year in tickets, because they are *really* aggressive. I have a friend who parked in a permit spot without a permit for 3 min to turn in a homework assignment, and when he came back he had a ticket. During the summer I would sometimes spend literally 45 minutes looking for a parking spot because all the lots were full.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Get a Permit or a Ticket Is Guaranteed â€“ Permits are reasonable but the campus police really search for cars without permits so they can ticket them. If you don't have a permit you WILL get ticketed. People usually ride bikes to class so finding a spot usually isn't an issue, but parking in an area where you don't have a permit always gets you a ticket. It sucks.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The Marguerite â€“ The Marguerite can take you pretty much anywhere you need to go, and there's a lot of different schedules for your convenience. Also, it's free, which is nice. I mean waiting on public transportation is never fun, but it gets you where you need to go, so it's not so bad. Also, it can take you to the caltrain, which will take you even further. Never order a taxi though, unless you're desperate. They are crazy expensive and hardly even worth it.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are a million ways to get involved around campus, from student organizations to on-campus employment, to research with faculty. Stanford makes it hard NOT to be involved!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Everyone Bikes â€“ Biking is a great way to get around the campus, almost no one walks, and cars are really only useful for getting into town. They're environmentally friendly, cheap, and fun!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: One of the most well-known landmarks of Stanford is Palm Drive. Palm trees are common on campus. The weather is perfect. It has cold and hot seasons, but the temperatures rarely leave the comfort zone.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Outrageously good--but of course it would be that way, being in the heart of Silicon Valley, having founded the likes of Sun, Yahoo, and Google. All dorms have fast wireless internet and public computers, and there are multiple computer labs scattered all around campus.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Palo Alto Isn't Great but Campus Is. It's a little dissappointing how expensive Palo Alto is but the campus always has something going on and you will never be bored. Visit San Francisco as much as possible because it's an amazing city and less than an hour away.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Academic Resources â€“ Stanford offers so many academic resources for students that are amazing and it would be a shame if you didn't take advantage of them. Professors are very open and friendly. There are tutors all over campus and in dorms. And you have the opportunity to expand your educational experience through our Bing Overseas Program where you will be offered to pay the same bill that you would if on campus.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Caltrain or Marguerite Is All You Need â€“ On campus we have a free bus system called the Marguerite which takes you not only around campus, but also to the local Stanford Shopping Center, downtown Palo Alot, and also to Mountain View where you can go to Walmart, Target, and Safeway. If you are trying to go up to San Francisco the Caltrain is the best option. Public buses are also efficient. Rental and zipcars are also available
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There is a range of different amazing buildings for the student interested in everything including ethnic community centers, a huge, state-of-the-art gym and a smaller one to supplement it in the center of campus, multiple libraries that have or will order for you any academic (and even non-academic) book that you could ever desire,a brand-new student union with a sports bar type eating facility and multiple meeting and study rooms, and in overall beautiful campus filled with palm trees and beautiful mission style architecture.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Safe and Prosperous Area, but Not Exciting â€“ Palo Alto seems like a nice, rich, clean, safe community. Our community right of campus seems to have a lot of money, and I'd wish somewhere more like San Francisco or Berkeley was right there for us. It takes forever to get there
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Stanford was built as a biking campus, which is evident in the extreme lack of parking. There are some large parking garages, but it generally can be hard to find a good spot. The perk is that you really DON'T need a car on campus.  Most students don't have one.  We just bike, which eliminates the parking problem and is better for the Earth.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Stanford has one of the best CS departments in the world, so it stands to reason that computers on campus are great.  Every computer in the computer clusters (each dorm has a room with multiple computers/scanners/printers)comes with things like MATLAB and all the Adobe products (Indesign, etc.) on them.  Wireless speed is amazing.  It makes me impatient about my home internet.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Nice but Expensive â€“ Palo Alto is a pretty nice hangout area but isn't financially realistic for most college students. Plus, University Ave. traffic can be realistic. Everything we need at Stanford is pretty much at Stanford.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Bike Your Way â€“ There aren't a lot of parking spots on campus besides in residential lots.  You don't need a car on campus if you have a bike.  The shuttle is also free.  The recent restrictions on day parking makes biking even more convenient.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Finding Balance â€“ One of the things qualities in students at Stanford that stands out in my mind is the ability to balance many different commitments. Everyone has such a wide range of interests, both academically or extracurricularly. Each student who was admitted had a really special quality about them (and more often than not, has done something really cool!), but they won't go around talking about it unless you truly get to know them.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Absolutely Perfect â€“ Maybe University of Hawaii has better weather than Stanford, but it would be close. It rains about 40% of the time between January and March, but warm sunshine is guaranteed for the rest of the year.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Buses Are Good, Zipcar Is Better â€“ The Marguerite runs regularly during the week, but isn't convenient enough on the weekends to make use of it. Stanford has plenty of Zipcars on campus, which makes it easy for students without a car to get off campus.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Every dorm has its own computer cluster, and there are others in other areas on campus. You can usually find a spot, but most people have their own. Printing on campus is $.10 per page. The network is fast and reliable, and you can get wireless anywhere on campus. I've never had a problem. Having a printer isn't necessary (there's one in every dorm and in the libraries), but having your own computer is best, although you could probably get away with not having one.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Great Campus, but I Wish We Had a Better Union â€“ The campus is gorgeous, but there's no real central place for students to hang out. Although Tressider Student Union has places to eat, and Old Union has plenty of couches and group study rooms, no one seems to really hang out there. The gym is nice, but way too far away for those on West Campus, like I am. Fortunately, they'll be building a new one on this side of campus that will open in 2013. The libraries have pretty much anything you would ever need or want, but if they don't, they'll get it for you from any number of other universities. It's easy to find a quiet place to study in Green Library, and there are group study areas in Meyer.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Stanford has a free bus that runs around the campus and to the nearby local train station and city of Palo Alto. Unfortunately, the train is really the only method of public transportation around, and it only goes to San Francisco. It's difficult to get to the airport on any sort of public transportation, and there are no Stanford-operated shuttles.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Everything Is Top-Of-The-Line â€“ This is Stanford, after all. It's hard to fully realize until you come here how many incredible facilities you have at your disposal, many of which you can use 24 hours per day.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's 70 degrees in January. What more could you want when it usually rains in Winter?
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Wish There Was More of a City Atmosphere â€“ Stanford is great because it offers so much to do within the bubble. Unfortunately, going out in any of the neighborhoods surrounding campus is boring, though I do love the Stanford Shopping Center. San Francisco and San Jose are close enough to make this less of an issue, but it's different from actually going to school in either city.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The marguerite shuttle can pretty much get you within walking distance of anywhere you want to go.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Convenient spaces go quickly on busy days, otherwise it's pretty good.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Amazing computer clusters everywhere.  Computing resources readily located and plenty of help for those who don't have any experience with computers or technology in general.  Most of the computers in the computer are the huge widescreen Macs, and they all have Mac OS or Windows 7 installed on all computers.  Some of the computers available for undergraduate science class that are connected to lab instruments such as the NMR are a bit outdated (some are really really outdated but still fully functioning).  Keyboards and mouse are great.  Remote printing is available and printing is not an issue, though it costs about a dime for every piece of paper printed.  Tons of computer labs everywhere across the campus and at least one in every dorm.  Wifi is pretty good, although the signal strength is kinda spotty in some places.  Network reliability is at its finest, no need to worry about information lost or slow connection.  Connection is incredibly fast when connected via ethernet.  Need for personal computer is not necessary, although it's just handy when you want to work at night or don't feel like leaving your room.  But while my laptop was broken, I was able to finish all my work using just the computer cluster.  A personal printer is also not necessary since you can print from your room and just pick it up at the computer cluster printers, but it's just handy to have around when you're in a rush.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are many libraries on campus besides the two main libraries, Meyer and Green, and nearly all of them contain working computers (both Mac and PC). The speed is great and wireless access is great all over campus (I even use the wifi for my phone instead of 3G for speed and to conserve battery). You have to pay for printing, but I have my own printer anyway, so I don't.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: World Class Experiences â€“ Stanford is a place that truly exposes you to the big players in the world in the process of nurturing you to join their ranks. It is a great place to network, or get experience in any field or art.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review:
Stanford is the best possible place for almost anything. 
It has a great balance of academics, extracurriculars, and social life. It has the best athletic department in the world. It has top ranked departments in almost every subject, from engineering to political science. There are resources from the Business, Med, and law school. 
Social life can be great if you want it to. Or you can hide in your room if you want to. 
Living at Stanford is actually paradise (with the exception of hard classes)
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
Libraries are good places to study and have everything you could want. Grad school libraries are a lot quieter. 
The campus is beautiful all year long. literally.
Campus activities are cool. They really make you feel like a Stanford student. Clubs and activities are always there, but because classes get hard during the middle and end of the quarter, clubs have their ups and downs in their level of commitment. 
For most people Arillaga (the gym), it great. It does the job but is frequently busy and it isn't that big.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: State of the art sports facilities, gorgeous weather throughout the year, and a powerhouse of both the humanities and engineers especially computer science, Stanford University is a heavenly palace in its own respect. Beautiful scenery, vast amount of space allowing an aura of creativity to exist, and many cultural events allows the student endless entertainment and activities to do. It definitely has a lot of International Students especially Asia, but the real prize is the diversity of students from all backgrounds providing conversation and understanding in this globalizing world. Beyond the academic prowess and plentiful libraries, Stanford has a feel of both tradition and modernity combining both the technology powerhouse with the grounding humanities and people from all walks of life. This is truly the place where leaders are created.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: This is the bay area, so it's not the typical California weather that you'd think.  The winters are generally cool, especially in the SF area, but it's not unreasonable.  The spring and summer times are nice.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: WIFI EVERYWHERE â€“ It seems like everywhere you are connected to the Internet and that's great. There's no need to carry a ethernet cord anywhere and the wifi never goes down.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Its January and 70 degrees. We do tend to have periods of rain though
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: parking is expensive, and if you park in the wrong spot you get ticketed very easily. Not fun.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Palo Alto is a high scale environment. There are alot of really cool boutiques in the area and they all have lots of unique items; however, many boutiques are very expensive.  They do have sales periodically, but there is no "regular" mall.  The closet mall is The Stanford Shopping Center and it is made up of Louis Vuitton, Burberry, Tiffany and Co, etc.  If you want really nice clothing, Palo Alto is the place to be, but it is very expensive.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: A full-year parking pass isn't too expensive. The marguerite is helpful. Zipcar is also very convenient.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Stanford will help you get anywhere and do anything.  The amounts of grants and leadership opportunities and clubs and professors who want to help you is outstanding.  The environment with other students helping you out is also great- very encouraging environment
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Stanford has a free shuttle called the Marguerite. It goes to all the major places on campus and even to shopping areas off campus. It also goes to the CalTrain station which goes all the way to San Francisco and down to Gilroy.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The weather is very nice year round. It's warm and sunny with blue sky almost every day except for a few weeks during the winter (which is rainy season). If you need seasons, you might get a little stir crazy, but otherwise, it's just like living at a resort. If you really need clouds, you can always go to San Francisco where it's quite foggy and much cooler.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review:
Great Wireless Access â€“ Computer Labs: Many present in libraries and dorms
Printing on Campus: Costs money!!! You must have your money on your Stanford ID card and an accounts set up to print...kind of annoying.
Network Reliability & Speed: Getting set up on the Stanford network requires a good twenty minutes, but afterwords internet is available literally everywhere on campus and it is quick. 
Wireless access: Great, everyone uses it. 
Personal Computer and Printer are very highly recommended.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Great Campus, Poor Social Scene â€“ The campus is full of things to do with amazing opportunities around every corner but the only social scene is the frat parties where drinking is the main activity.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Great for Free â€“ the marguarite is very useful for all transportation needs but is very slow and half the drivers don't even speak english
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: No Need for a Car â€“ There is no use for a car for normal campus life and the only use would be for pleasure.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Stanford is a gorgeous campus. Our school does pride itself in its beauty, though I think that money could be better used to fund student programs and financial aid. Though I guess the appearance of a campus is important to continue attracting students. Furthermore, the social life is rather dull. Our greek system is not developed like many schools in the south or east coast. Stanford students also don't have extravagent parties, they will have one here and there but that usually involves off-campus students as well. As far as the academic rigour, well its true, its tough but doable. I give Stanford a B-, because though it has great academic standings, its social scene is not all that great, the support I have had has been one that is not fitting to students that come from poverished environments, and finally because there is an overwhelming waste of funds. There are children dying of hunger in countries and students at Stanford take their food for granted and throw a lot away. Stanford has tried to become sustainable and improve on their waste, but it still is a problem. Furthermore, the budget and the fact that so much goes to keeping the campus so nice when some of its employees are not given the pay they deserve for working so hard also disgusts me. I would like to see President Hennessy cleaning the Law School or other Stanford Facilities after-hours and survive with the pay of these employees for a week. Well this is enough, Stanford is my school and I am glad to have come here, but it still has a lot to work on, which is not a bad thing. A lot of schools have a lot to work on, nothing is perfect. The one good note is, Stanford does make the effort to make things better.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Usually Great â€“ The weather is great for college. Usually warm during the day but cool at night and in the morning so the lack of a/c in the dorms is not a big deal. It can get pretty cold and rainy at times, but the sunny perfect weather toward the end of the year is worth the wait. It is kind of annoying how the weather canchange from hot to cold so quickly though
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Lots to Do â€“ There's nothing lacking at Stanford. Beautiful libraries, a plethora of activities, and the gym is huge with lots of PE classes and things like rock climbing, squash courts, and racquetball courts. You want something? You'll most likely find it somewhere on campus. And it's just a beautiful place to walk and discover things.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Good Luck? Parking can be a real hassle at Stanford. There are several different types of parking permits based on region, and for the reasonably priced cheaper permits, it can be hard to find paring close to where you want to go. Luckily, Stanford is working on building more, like the Wilbur Parking Lot.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The weather here is truly paradise. Warm all year round, and sunny for all but a couple weeks in January or February.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Beautiful, Huge Campus â€“ There are no complaints about the campus. It's beautiful, large, sunny, and well maintained. There are two gyms, 2 main libraries (plus a dozen or so smaller ones), great Greek life on weekends, a large and comfortable student center, and loads of cafes. One downside though is that most of the cafe's don't take meal plan dollars, so you wind up just going to one or two.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Great Transport â€“ It's very easy to get around without a car. The Marguerite shuttle system will get you nearly anywhere around campus, and several places in town, for free. And if you want to go further afield, CalTrain and a variety of buzzes can cheaply take you anywhere in the Bay Area. You can take your bike on both Marguerite and CalTrain, too.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are always empty computers in the libraries, although you might have trouble finding one during finals week. There are also a few large computer clusters on campus, as well as a lot of small ones. In fact, each dorm has its own computer cluster room and a student Resident Computer Consultant to help you if you have any problems with the school's computer or your own. The wireless network is very fast and reliable.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The gorgeous weather, proximity to San Francisco & the beach, variety of classes and extracurriculars, plus all the special programs provide an abundance of opportunities and make for a great campus experience. Stanford has the largest college campus in North America, not to mention at least a dozen or so study abroad campuses. It's easy for undergrads to do research, and it's just an all-around amazing place to go to school.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Awesome Everything â€“ There isn't just one thing that makes Stanford special. Stanford excels in some many ways that what ever you want to do Stanford is probably one of the best places to do it.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Not a Good College Town â€“ Palo Alto is not a good college town. There isn't much to do and everything is pretty expensive.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: In the Heart of the Silicon Valley â€“ Being the heart of the Silicon Valley provides for an experience unlike any other. It's crazy how sucked into the techie culture everyone gets. In truth, however anti-trust a student may be, most learn to fall in love with corporations like Apple and Google, and probably think it wouldn't be that bad if they took over the world (Facebook is a given for like every college student, no?).
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Rains a Lot â€“ When the sun comes out, it is definitely a very pleasant experience. However, I suppose I had high expectations because of the reputation that California has. It is usually not as warm as I would like it to be or that I'm used to. Also, it rains a lot more than I thought it would. I came prepared for sunshine year round, and instead got regular rain showers, especially during the winter.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Bikes Are the Way to Go â€“ Probably everyone on the Stanford campus owns a bike. Students, instructors, deans, everyone rides a bike. This makes for an interesting experience during rush hour, as hundreds of bikes commute around the Quad. Accidents abound, but usually no one gets hurt. The Marguerite, the free Stanford shuttle, is a good option to head into Palo Alto or go to the mall.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Stanford is the mecca of IT. Therefore, not owning a computer is considered akin to not having an arm. There is still, however, a computer cluster in ever dorm, with computers, a printer, and a lot of fancy software. The computers at Green library are kind of old but work perfectly, and you can borrow all kinds of computer equipment from Meyer Library. Wireless extends all around the Stanford campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: No Cars, Please â€“ Stanford is completely bike-centered. Cars, on the other hand, are more of a no-no here. To begin with, freshmen aren't allowed to have cars for the duration of the whole year. Which, kinda sucks. Upperclassmen are allowed to park their car near their dorm, although to get a permit you have to fill out an application, and are unofficially expected to move around campus on their bikes, only using the car for outings.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Not Too Shabby â€“ The facilities at Stanford are, for the most part, state of the art and very valuable to student life. Campus itself is beautiful with a lot of pride held in the aesthetics of the landscape. There are plenty of different food places to choose from, quiet places to study, places to get together for group projects, an art museum, and very nice athletic centers.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: No Need â€“ There isn't really a need for car on campus because it's a fairly small campus that's contiguous. Also, cars aren't allowed on the parts of campus where the classes are held though they are allowed in the outskirts. Permits aren't available to freshmen unless you have connections, and they will ticket you if your car is illegally parked. Cars aren't necessarily needed on campus, however, Stanford is basically a bubble school and a car is the best way of escaping the bubble on weekends.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Seriously the campus is drop dead gorgeous.  Stanford is ALWAYS undergoing renovation/building something new (right now a concert hall is being constructed).  Dorms are given money to essentially buy things for themselves.  Last year, my dorm bought a flatscreen TV with surround-sound speakers, a new ping pong table, a foosball table, and still had tons of money to spare.  If I had to pick weak points of campus, I would pick Meyer Library, I guess.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
I Am in Love â€“ Seriously, Stanford (though I didn't know it before I got here) is my dream school. I have made the friends of a lifetime here.  The people are, for the most part, amazingly chill.  They are intelligent, but very humble about their accomplishments.  They love to have fun (be it fountain hopping or frat hopping).  The athletic programs are nationally recognized, winning 4 NCAA championships in the last year. The classes are amazing.  Rarely do you not get into a class you want. The professors are not only brilliant, but also friendly and approachable (for the most part). The campus is stunningly beautiful. What more could you want out of a school?  

Oh and the wonderful thing is, you would be hard pressed to find a Stanford student that feels differently.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: BIKES BIKES BIKES â€“ As a student who does not have a car on campus, biking is my primary mode of transport, and it works wonderfully.  Zipcars are available for reasonable prices to those who want to rent them.  In fact, the nearby Avis even lets under-21's rent their cars.  Furthermore, Caltrain and the Marguerite (campus bus system) ensure that you have the means to get anywhere you please.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: All students have the opportunities they work for and desire - Stanford opens so many doors.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Stanford has a reputable undergrad education that is bolstered by a community of staff and faculty who are committed to finding part time jobs, internships, and other opportunities for pre-professional experiences outside of the classroom. Situated at the heart of Silicon Valley, recruitment for techies (engineering and computer science majors) and prospective consultants is intense and competitive. We have top ranking business, law, and medical schools, and these connections have definitely helped undergrads. Alumni participation, with events such as Homecoming Reunion and the Alumni Club, is very strong, making us the first university to raise $1 billion dollars in fundraising efforts. With resources in Student Career Education such as BEAM and the online platform Handshake, Stanford really wants to help its students be fully equipped after graduation.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I feel very confident that I will find internships, jobs, and careers in the future.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I'm not too worried about career prospects because I believe a degree from this school is valued very highly.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Employers do very well in Career Fairs in promoting their name and recruiting potential employees.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: A Stanford degree can get you pretty much anywhere.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: There is simply nothing that is as valuable to me as I go forward as my Stanford degree
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: The name of the school is well-known which helps!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It has a great alumni network, and because everyone knows of the school, it is easier to find jobs after college
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Beyond the prestigious name that Stanford has, the university will put you in contact with the kinds of people who are best positioned to maximize your success. The university wants famous alum after all!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review:
The alumni network is incredible. 

A Stanford degree is apparently super sought-after, and people generally get good jobs after graduating. Many doors are apparently open to those of us who graduate from here etc. etc.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: lots of networking and internship opportunities
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: From my experience, research positions and internships are handed to students. Also, being located in the Silicon Valley, we have great access to tech job recruiting.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The "Stanford name" is no joke. Lots of alumni willing to help out and lots of recruitment opportunities/career services advice on campus.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I have already utilized the wide network of Stanford connections, and while I feel almost like I'm cheating the system, I could not be more grateful for the opportunities I have had. I feel like if I continue working hard and keeping my options open and using my resources, I will have little trouble finding the funding to pursue any position that I choose. As an International Relations major with a desire to pursue politics, I look forward to returning to DC to give back to Stanford what it gave to me - - a wealth of experiences.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Having a Stanford degree has opened many doors for me.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Lot's of alumni participation, lots of jobs opp.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: In case you didn't know, Stanford is really, really rich. While the sticker price is intimidatingly high, the financial aid department is generous with their funding, and Stanford is often more affordable to lower income students than other colleges and universities.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Though I did not apply for financial aid, I am astonished at the aid available.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: Just talk to the financial aid counselors.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: A degree from Stanford is very helpful in getting a job after college as well as for internships during college. The career center is helpful and there are very many top companies as well as startups from Silicon Valley recruiting on campus.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I got quite a bit of financial aid which was necessary because my brother is also at a prestigious college.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Lots of recruiters on campus throwing free stuff at us (especially the CS majors) ALL the time. Career guidance center is pretty solid too
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Financial aide is good. If you get in, they'll make sure that you can pay to go. Not necessarily that it's going to be cheap or easy to go, but that you definitely can go if you so choose. I'm on 50% financial aide (making it almost comparable to paying for a state school) and have a yearly household income in the very very low 6 digits. A friend I have who has a a single-parent family and a 30,000-40,000ish income pays like 3000 or 5000 a year, I think. Stanford provides ONLY need-based scholarships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid office will work with you for any problem.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It is best to make an appointment in person.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Getting a job after school is not a worry for almost anyone. People seem to literally fall over themselves to give jobs to Stanford students, and if one can't find a job, both the alumni network and the career center are extraordinarily helpful.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Lots of doors are opened when you go to Stanford!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I got a ton of money in financial aid from Stanford. I wouldn't have been able to pay the $60,000+ per year costs if it wasn't for need based financial aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Depends, but overall the weight of the name alone carries it well. Computer Science and tech majors in general will have no trouble finding a job.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I am buying a brand not an education
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Got nothing and had to take out lots of loans
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Stanford is ranked in the top 5 for financial aid and endowment in the country. Anyone whose parents make less than $60,000 comes entirely free, and many whose parents make less than $100,000 is tuition free. For many students, coming to Stanford is cheaper than their state college.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Stanford is good at helping with the process.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Apply on time and send in your required documents. Stanford is wonderful in meeting financial need, and out of the schools I applied to, Stanford gave me the most in scholarship money! If you have too many outside scholarships, they might deduct some from your need-based aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Understandably getting financial aid is not easy here
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: My financial aid package has gradually gotten worse, despite my family's worsening financial situation.  The university was willing to listen and was somewhat accommodating, but I will be leaving with a significant amount of debt.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Financial aid is pretty generous to most students.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Stanford makes it relatively easy to get financial aid, however they don't tell you about a lot of hidden costs. Also any other scholarship you gain from outside sources they just deduct from the amount they plan to give you so don't expect to be able to use that money. Meet with the financial aid office a lot and they will try to help you as best as possible. They are very friendly.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: When applying to college, Stanford actually offered me the largest financial aid package of all the colleges I applied to, and it was all need-based. A world-class education isn't cheap, but Stanford is very generous in ensuring that you can attend without too much financial hardship.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Easy and Available â€“ Stanford asks for only two things, FAFSA and CSS Profile. I was given enough aid to make it the most affordable college for me!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The Best Package Ever! Stanford gives you all that you need and more! I will graduate without a loan to my name, thank you Stanford!
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review:
Stanford has one of the best financial aid programs in the country. I am a resident of California, and Stanford offered me the largest scholarship of any California school, including the UCs, and substantially more than many liberal arts schools that I applied to. The Financial Aid Office is amazingly friendly and helpful, and I have worked with them many a time on turning in forms and making sure that I had everything taken care of well before the deadline.
Did you know that even if you pay full tuition, it costs Stanford more than that to actually keep you here as a student? That extra money comes from donors, sports, and research. You can't put a price on the Stanford experience, and that's the truth.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The school knows that students come from different walks of life. It does its very best to make sure that a student is not hindered by his/her financial situation.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Financial Aid is awesome.  The only person I know with a problem has issues because her Dad died in high school and things with insurance are crazy, but she talked with financial aid and they figured out a way for her to be able to stay here without too much in loans.  I am frickin broke and I get to live more or less the same way as the super rich people do.  Pretty awesome!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Paying Is Not a Problem â€“ Stanford has lots of money to spend, so financial aid is a breeze. They assess how much money you can pay and they don't charge a dollar more. They can afford to do that. Since a lot of their students get into Harvard and Yale, they have to offer good financial aid to stay competitive.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Everybody at Stanford deserves a full-ride at a state school, so all the money the University gives is needs-based. So if you want a scholarship from the school, get your parents to quit their jobs and live off welfare, because if you do have the need, they'll pay for you to come to Stanford.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Process Could Have Been a Little More Smooth â€“ Stanford has an AMAZING financial aid award that I think beats most other schools. However, if you have issues with your student bill or financial aid, those are two separate offices that handle only certain part of your bill so it can be somewhat of a hassle going back and forth between the two departments.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I was really worried that I wouldn't get enough aid to go to Stanford, as I fall in the "middle class crunch," but Stanford gave me the money that I needed. They only ask for a fraction of parents' and students' savings per year as well, instead of taking everything that you've saved up. People I've talked to have had good experiences with aid, especially lower-income students who are actually given money in order to buy school supplies and textbooks.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Summer's Arent Covered...But You Wouldn't Know That. Stanford offers (basically) full financial aid to any student whose parents make less than $60,000 a year, but what they don't tell you is that aid doesn't count for the summer, so you end up having to take out a loan. Since they didn't warn you you may have a hold on your account while you come to the realization and deal with the aftermath.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: If You Need It, You Got It â€“ Stanford has a need-blind application system, meaning that they don't even consider your financial standing until they've admitted you. Then, they have very low thresholds for financial aid, so anyone who actually needs it, gets it. I've received all the help I needed, all four years!
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Financial aid is amazing. No loans, 100% need met.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Good to Go â€“ Stanford gives a lot of financial aid for the student who really need it.  Unfortunately the people who are generally middle class, but could still use some assistance are usually left out of financial aid.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: GREEEAT Money Money Money! I LOVE the financial aid system here. None of the other schools I applied to gave me any money at all yet Stanford gave a substantial amount of money to help me out. They are very understanding and are quite generous in their financial contributions.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I didn't get anything from Stanford.  Its one of those places where most kids are too rich to get financial aid and too poor to pay for school.  I know lots of kids on loans.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Not Enough â€“ I got a reasonable amount of aid, but it was not enough because everything else is on loan and that's going to take forever to pay off. Hopefully I get more next year. I wish money wasn't such a central point in our society.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I received full need-based financial aid with basically no work on my part.  Checks are automatically deposited in my account at the beginning of each quarter.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Wasn't a Piece of Cake â€“ Stanford has tons of money to dish out but the actual process of receiving aid takes a while. There are a number of steps and while they try to make it easy to handle, there are still a number of mistakes students or administration can make. Fortunately, the Financial Aid Office is very welcoming and really wants to sort out any issues you may have.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Lots of good restaurants in Palo Alto. Lunch/dinner is usually pretty expensive, so I usually just go for ice cream/coffee/a snack.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food is good compared to most colleges. Lots of options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Significantly better than food at most universities, lots of vegetarian options, pretty decent variety, etc. Prices are less than ideal.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining halls are ok, but it also depends on the day.  There is fairly good variety but some dining halls are definitely better than others
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Off-campus dining can be a little hard to discover, since it's mostly accessible only by bike (downtown Palo Alto and California Ave are the go-to biking places). Once you have a car, or if you use a delivery service (Doordash, Fluc, etc), you can discover a ton of different options. There's a pretty big variety of cuisines available if you know where to look. Don't just settle for what's on University Ave. One thing about this area in general though: everything is expensive. Food is mostly not college-priced, and a $10 meal is not that easy to come by. However, there is some really good, fairly expensive food nearby. There're lots of different types of cuisine available, including some really good Italian, Mexican, Indian (try Sunnyvale), Chinese (iDumpling) and French. Good food, but a pricey if you're in the Palo Alto area.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The meal plan's main drawback is how expensive it is. However, there are a lot of dining halls conveniently placed to pretty much every dorm. There are also options if you don't want to be on the standard dining hall meal plan, such as living on the Row or in an apartment.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The off campus dining is great, the only thing that would make it better is if it were slightly closer!
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Being a vegan on campus is extraordinarily easy and yummy.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Downtown Palo Alto is really close and a lot of students will go off campus and eat at the local restaurants which all seem great.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food options are exceptional even if you are vegan .. sometimes the food lacks flavor to accommodate all students but generally some option you can look forward to in the dining halls. If not late night is always a good option.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Have you ever tried to eat in Palo Alto? If yes, you know why you wouldn't do it the next time. If no, don't start unless you are starving and the nearest kitchen if an hour away. Totally pointless waste of time and money.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: The food is really bad at this part of the West coast, and Stanford campus is no exception. Occasionally, you may find something somehow eatable but that's about it. If you have been born and raised in NorCal, than that may be OK for your taste. Otherwise, prepare to suffer.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: With the San Francisco area available outside of campus, it is pretty easy to find good dining options off campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Lots of variety and extremely healthy. Have some really delicious foods, but depends on the day.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
Palo Alto is like 75% restaurants and furniture stores. Restaurants can be pricey, but a wide range of options and high quality is available.

Lots of people use doordash to order food from restaurants like CREAM, the Cheesecake Factory, Oren's Hummus, Thaiphoon, various burger places, places that sell boba, etc.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Variety and quality is leaps and bounds above other dining programs at other schools. Today for lunch I had samosas, tamarind chutney, rice and tandoori chicken at Stern Dining and it was delicious. Lunch/brunch tend to be the best meals, dinner is usually good but not *as* good as lunch. The dining ambassador program allows students to ask for specific meals/provide input to the dining staff on food, and usually once or twice a quarter one of the dining halls will throw a massive ethnic-themed dinner with really really high quality food. Wilbur has Lunar New Year, FloMo has Diwali, Stern has Dia de los Muertos and Cinco de Mayo, Lagunita has Mardi Gras. We have had a plant-based protein push in the halls this year, which is a bit disappointing for those of us who really really like meat, but there is always AT LEAST one or two meats each meal and one or two non-meat options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
Dining hall food is pretty good, especially if you know where to go (Manzanita has good food, and Stern has gotten similarly yummy in recent years). There are also Late-Nite services in Arillaga and Lagunita dining halls (9pm-2am I think), which offer delicious snacks and meals Sunday-Thursday. If you live in a house (different from a dorm, and only open to upper-classemen), then you will either have a in-house chef who cooks meals just for your house (they're usually quite good, and some houses are famous campus-wide for their food) or house residents will take turns cooking meals for the entire house. Whether you have a chef or are responsible for cooking depends on where you live. 

There are a few restaurants on campus--Mediterranean, Subway, Starbucks, Treehouse (Mexican/American), The CoHo (coffee and generally healthy meals), The Axe and Palm (wide variety, but famous for its burgers), Coupa Cafe (organic-y/healthy food and great coffee), and a teeny hole-in-the-wall Thai place on the bottom floor of the math building in the main quad, open 11am-2pm M-F, and which looks sketchy but is actually very delicious. There are also food trucks around campus, but you pay for their admittedly tasty food with pretty steep prices.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: If there's one thing Palo Alto does offer college students, its food. Lots and lots of varied, delicious food. Students can take a free shuttle to University Avenue and nearby cross-streets, which have a huge variety of restaurants (Indian, Israeli, Thai, American, Chinese, Argentinian, Italian, etc.). Food here can be a little pricey though, depending on the restaurant. If you go further off campus (you either have to have a car, a friend with a car, or rent a Zip Car/Uber for this) there are cheaper options, and just as wide and delicious a variety.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Because Stanford is so big, off-campus options are not very likely, unless one has a car.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There are many many options
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Palo Alto and Menlo Park offer a variety of restaurants
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Meal plan dollars should be accepted at more places
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Love the food off campus!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Palo Alto isn't a college town any more, and the restaurants tend to be pretty pricey. But the quality is great, and there are many options if you have the money.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Downtown Melbourne may have a boring nightlife but there are lots of nice local restaurants to experience. There are also a number of fast food options in the local area.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Food quality is good for the quantity it is produced in. However after a few weeks it becomes very difficult to find variety in the food eaten, meaning students must go from the main dining hall to the outside food services which are more expensive and require flex cash.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Dining halls are numerous, diverse, and have overall pretty good food. There are several other restaurant options on campus, and dining dollars are able to be used for a few. Not to mention Starbucks, Thai Cafe, Coupa, Treehouse, and others
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: San Fran close by makes it ok.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: You just have to know which dining halls are the best
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Tons of restaurants, they're just rather expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The location of the university makes it a bit difficult to find places.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Stanford dining is the best. I expected college food to be not so appetizing, but the dining halls have so many options. There are also specific dining halls that are culturally themed (Mexican/ Asian Food). I am never hungry. Also since I started college I have gone vegetarian and they have a huge selection of vegetarian options as well. Meal plan dollars are great to use at places such as Subway, Olives, The Axe and Palm, and Late Night. Stanford has the greatest (and also most caring) dining halls, that I feel spoiled.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Oren's Hummus is a great place to check out. Cream has the best ice-cream sandwiches by far! Some Palo Alto restaurants are more expensive than others but are only a short distance walking or biking off campus. Great variety and delicious foods.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Most off campus dining is pretty expensive, so I rarely go often campus to eat.  University Avenue is the main place students go to eat off campus.  If you can afford it, there are a lot of vegan/ vegetarian and healthy food options, as well as a decent variety of options, including Thai, mediterranean, pizza, etc.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are some great places in Palo Alto, but they can be expensive and hard to get to, given how far campus is removed from downtown.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The dining in Palo Alto is very overpriced. While there are a variety of options, most of the time due to price and lack of convenience, most students will rarely eat off campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Stanford does a fantastic job of giving a wide variety of food, and the chefs are always rotating available dishes from week to week. Meals are usually swipe to eat, and the quality is definitely good enough to get a satisfying meal. Chefs are friendly and know what they are doing. The only downside is the lack of non-dining-hall restaurants on/near campus, as well as viable late night options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a lot of different dining halls, so you can mix it up. Plus, you are given meal plan dollars that you can use at places like Olives and TAP. All in all, especially compared to other schools I have eaten at, we have it made at Stanford.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Nearby downtown Palo Alto has lots of vegan/vegetarian options but it is expensive and you have to drive/take the bus to get there. Also, they don't have pearl milk tea (boba), which is a huge letdown in my opinion.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's pretty good food, but some choices might be too expensive.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: I find many of the choices to be monotonous, but most of the food is tolerable. I thought we had it bad until I visited some dining halls at other schools and I realized how good we have it! The repetition is what's most annoying, not the food itself.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Stanford has a number of nice places to go off campus to eat, the only question is finding it. Definitely ask around for good places to eat, or maybe use Yelp. There's some really nice places in downtown Palo Alto, I suggest the Cheesecake Factory and the Darbar Indian Restaurant. Note, though, that most of the places are pretty expensive, but that's what you should expect in Palo Alto.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is a lot of diversity, but, the food quality is not what you would expect from a top-tier private university
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a lot of restaurant right off campus in Palo Alto on university ave, they are also really good, however the problem is that pretty much all of them are really expensive. So much money is spent just trying to get food on a Friday night with friends.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a variety of different dining halls that serve different types of food. It's generally true that dining hall food starts tasting bland after a while, but I think this is true of most universities.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I really like Stanford dining. They are  great in terms of healthy, vegetarian/ethnic food selections, cleanliness, friendliness, etc. The dining hall staff are great. You are free to take food back to your dorms. The best dining places, in my opinion, are Arillaga and Lagunita, but most everywhere is pretty good. I'm not a huge fan of FloMo though...
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The menus can be changed when asked and the staff is very friendly. The meals depend from different dining halls, and makes it ore fun to go and try new places. It is not possible to avoid the freshman 15 here.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food is not too bad although it can get a little repetitive.  There are other places to eat besides dining halls, so you can get some variety if you really want it.  There are many places one can use meal plan dollars, too.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: University Avenue Is the BOMB â€“ Great choices down University Ave, and of course, down El Camino (California Ave, etc). Can get a bit pricey, but there are cheap options out there.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Good Variety â€“ There are many cool restuarants in downtown Palo Alto, but they tend to be a little pricey for college students
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Access Is Difficult â€“ Not a lot of people have cars on campus because it is more bike and walking oriented. Also, Northern California doesn't seem to have a lot of fast food anyway so there are a lot of relatively expensive restaurants. I only really go off campus to eat for "big" occasions or a couple of times per quarter.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It Really Depends on Where You Live â€“ There are a lot of dining halls and kitchens on campus, so there's a pretty wide variety of experiences you can have. In my experience, the dining halls can get pretty repetitive, but the food is always good. The houses have chefs, so those are always really good, but you don't have a lot of options since the chef usually just cooks one meal. Tressidder is always nice too if you have money because you can get subway, panda express, and a couple of other really good things like Treehouse or CoHo.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Nice Meals With Healthy Options â€“ The meal plans vary based on how many meals you wish to consume daily or weekly.  I'm a big eater so I have a complete meal plan.  I'm also a healthy eater and appreciate the assortment of vegetable, chicken and fish dishes offered.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Many Excellent Options â€“ For dorm food, Stanford is very good. The best dining halls to eat at are Ricker and FloMo, but others, like Arrillaga, are also good. The one to avoid is Stern; it's the only dining hall at Stanford that can truly be called bad. You can choose between a 19-, 14-, and 10-meal plan, and if you choose the 14- or 10-meal plan, you also get Meal Plan Dollars which you can use to purchase a la carte items.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Head Down El Camino Real â€“ The area around Stanford's not much for catering to student tastes (and wallets) so I avoid University Avenue, but if cheap is what you're looking for, just a ways down the main road there's a few gems if you've got the free time to bike, drive, or hitch a ride on the bus. A Boston Market with tasty sandwiches and amazing macaroni and cheese, the ever-popular In & Out Burger, and even the elusive Dairy Queen can be found within a relatively short distance. Head down the road the other way and there's a Safeway within easy biking distance, a convenience when it comes to late-night cravings.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The Closest Options Can Be Pretty Pricey. Downtown Palo Alto is a short mile-bike ride away from campus, and is the closest option for off-campus dining. Because of the affluent nature of Palo Alto, it's hard to find a meal bargain downtown.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
Lots of Variety â€“ Overall, Stanford has some incredible dining options.  You will always find something you like, whether it is at the salad bar, the mexican corner, or the asian buffet, most dining halls cater for all tastes.  There are definitely lots of options for vegetarians and vegans as well.  Stern Hall (generally mexican themed) has the reputation to be the worst dining hall, but even that has a decent selection every day.  Wilbur Hall is great, and their Asian food attracts people from all over campus.  The new dining hall, Arillaga is great as well, and puts a lot of emphasis of healthy dining and on making the food look really nice.  Indian food sunday at FloMo is quite good (as far as western standards go) and if you have friends at the Row, youa re in for a treat (get invited to their dining halls, they have their own chefs and their food is great)!

The one must visit place is definitely "Ike's" sandwich place in the engineering quad.  Their sandwiches on their signature Dutch Crunch bread are absolutely mouth watering.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Yummy Food! I really love the dining hall food. There are some students who complain about the food, but I would have to say the dining halls provide us a variety of foods to choose from.  The quality of the food is excellent! Unlike many other colleges where the food options tend to be more fast-food orientated, Stanford has many healthy food options.  The salad bars are great.  There are chicken breast upon request.  Brown rice, roasted vegetables, stiry-fry, fruits, so many options!  Some dining halls may have more variety than others, but overall you are bound to have something nourishing to eat.  This may not apply to more picky individuals though.  There's also a dining hall for people who are allergic to nuts.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Parent's Weekend Town â€“ The off-campus dining options are great and varied but Palo Alto is an expensive town. There are student discounts given with ID or with coupons that every student is given at the beginning of the year but the best resturants are the ones you ask your parents to go to on Parent's Weekend not with your friends. The variety and quality is great, the prices are not. Best places for students: Pluto's, Crepevine, The Counter, and countless fro-yo places
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Healthy Options and Flexible Meal Plans â€“ Stanford is all about sustainable food and provides lots of options for types of food and there is variety at every meal. A new dining hall just opened on east campus (where most frosh live) that is beautiful and full of healthy food. Stanford, for the most part, tries and succeeds to provide its students with a variety of options that are healthy and flavorful.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Plenty of Options â€“ There is abundance of good eateries in Palo alto, and many, many more along the El Camino. If you don't have a car, which you won't freshman year, it is harder to enjoy this dining. However, if you are willing to make the short drive of campus, your efforts will be rewarded with a bunch of great dining options. Use yelp.com to help narrow it down.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Palo Alto Is Restaurant Heaven â€“ University Avenue has every kind of restaurant you could imagine, from authentic French and Italian bistros to award-winning grills -- not to mention at least a dozen different dessert places. What's more, it's only a two minute drive or seven minute bike ride away. The only downside is the price, seeing as Palo Alto is one of the highest income areas in the country. Downtown Menlo Park has some more casual and inexpensive options, like bars, cafes, and diners, and is only a five minute drive from campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Fresh Food â€“ The school has a great dining staff. The foods are made from ingredients that come from the local market. Everything is fresh. The dining halls take into consideration each individual's personal dietary needs. There are a lot of options for vegans and vegetarians.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: University Ave!! There are some great food options on University Avenue which is a short 10 minute bike ride down Palm Drive. There is a great selection of food, the only problem is some places are a little pricey. If you venture off onto some of the side streets you can find some hidden gems that won't break the bank.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Yay, Food! The food at the dining halls is good, but there are also a lot of non-dining hall options available. Many places, like the Axe & Palm, Union Square, Subway, etc. accept meal plan dollars - which is nice :).
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Many Options - Expensive â€“ There are some great restaurants off-campus and many students go out on Fridays or Saturdays but it is palo alto and prices will reflect that.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I Liked the Food â€“ I think the food is solid. I never had a problem with variety or taste. Although every once in a while you feel like you've seen the menu - it's expected after four years. Granted I'm not a picky eater, and there were some complaints about food, I think there are some great dishes cooked up across campus. They try to be flexible to students needs and tastes too and often provide a build-you-own station for things like pasta/panini/omelettes etc.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Sort of Expensive â€“ Being in downtown Palo Alto, the restaurants within walking distance can be a bit expensive. I haven't personally used any, but there are quite a few that offer student discounts. The best way to find cheaper places or more variety is to have a car, unfortunately.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There are awesome places to get food off campus, though most are very nice, sit down spots. Be ready to pay a pretty penny. The variety is great, especially ethnic restaurants. Great Korean, Middle Eastern, Thai, Spanish, Italian. You can also find a quick-stop "college" type of place if you seek it, but do not think there are hole-in-the-wall-amazing stops all around. If you venture out, though, you can find about anything.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review:
Best Food Is Found in Self-Ops â€“ self-ops offer the best food hands down because they have chefs. plus the food is cooked in small quantity so the quality is high. these type of houses also have open kitchen, so you can grab as many snacks as you like after hours or whip up your own food if you don't like what the chef made. 


problem is that only so many people can get into a self-op house, so most people (and all freshmen) are stuck eating at the dining halls. Regular dining hall food is truly hit or miss, mostly miss. wilbur dining has the best dining hall food in my opinion. furthermore, brunch is usually good across the board at all dining halls.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Pricey in Palo Alto, Cheaper Elsewhere â€“ Downtown Palo Alto is a 10 minute bike ride from campus (and free shuttles run from campus to Palo Alto every 45 min or so). There is a great selection of food for different palates (Thai, Chinese, French crepes, Indian, vegan, sushi, Italian, froyo), but since it is an affluent area prices are high. Expect to spend at least $15 per entree for most of the restaurants. That said, there are a few student-friendly restaurants: Darbar, an Indian restaurant, has student 2-for-1 coupons; Siam Royal is good and relatively cheap Thai restaurant; Pizza My Heart has giant, New York-style pizza slices for $3. If you have a car, you can venture to Mountain View or Sunnyvale or Menlo Park, which have cheaper choices. I recommend Celia's (a local Mexican chain) and Tofu House.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Great Food â€“ The food is definitely better than other colleges that I've visited.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Pretty Good! a lotta people complain, but im happy. the ice cream is to die for
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Overpriced and Overrated â€“ It's palo alto. If you wanna pay $25 for sushi, then this is the place for you.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Expensive in General â€“ There is fast food on El Camino Real and a few restaurants, if you don't want to spend a lot of money on off-campus options.  In downtown Palo Alto, the shops and restaurants are too expensive for the college student.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Awesome variety. You can check out menus at a bunch of different dining halls and then decide where to go. You can also eat at Row Houses once you get to know some upperclassmen which offers the opportunity for some great food.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Better Than Most, but Not Great â€“ The dining halls are okay, but the real fine dining happens at the co-ops and self-ops around campus. Plus, there are great non-dining hall eateries (Treehouse, Axe and Palm) that are on campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: University Avenue Is Great! Downtown Palo Alto has a lot of great places to eat. It's an easy bike ride straight down Palm Drive which takes you right on to University Avenue. There are plenty of fun, delicious places to check out. Some places are a bit expensive, but you can find ones that aren't so bad.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Palo Alto Is Not a College Town â€“ Palo Alto is nice for romantic, intimate, small excursions, but it is by no means a college town. Cheap food and cheap fun are options that exist more readily a ride away on the Caltrain to Redwood City or San Francisco.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Florence Moore Hall â€“ Best food of all the dining halls AND you get ice cream every meal!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Great for Healthy Eaters â€“ Dining halls have very good healthy options - food is much better than most public schools and the fruit and vegetables are better than the Ivy League schools I have been to (Harvard, Princeton, Penn.) However, the food can get slightly repetitive, as it is mainly healthier food options, and it might not be your favorite if you like gourmet or comfort food. There are a few off campus places that work with meal plans, and dining off campus is first rate, but incredibly expensive because Palo Alto is expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Expensivo but Good Choice. There's a variety of great restaurants on University Avenue from California Pizza Kitchen to Miyake to Cheesecake Factory but alot are kind of pricey aka not for the student budget. However, there are a couple of small cafe's/deli's that are accessible and they are quite affordable. You just need to explore.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Great Food â€“ The food at Stanford is both delicious and nutritious. There is a wide variety of choices and alot of ethnic foods too.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Good Restaurants on University Ave. There are a lot of good places on the main street as soon as you leave campus (University Avenue). There are many different cuisines to pick from. Some of the places are a bit pricier because of the location but there are many (excellent) places that fit within a college budget.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review:
Dining Halls: Undergraduate Dining Halls offer standard college meals...Ricker and Florence Moore Dining hall offer better options
Menus: Menus are often repetitive, especially dessert
Variety: Dining halls could work on mastering cooking different cuisines such as Chinese and Mexican (for example)...you have mastered cooking chicken!
Value: Overall, the value is good. I feel that I am getting my money's worth. 
Best Places: Ricker (Dining Hall), Florence Moore (Dining Hall), Olives (you can use meal plan dollars here), Bytes Cafe (Cash or Credit Card), The Panini Place in Tressider (mos delicious paninis ever) and, if you are lucky enough to eat here, The Faculty Club (a professor must invite you to eat here first). 
Meal Plans: 12, 14 or 19 meal a week plan...if you opt for less than 19 meals a week you will get cardinal dollars which can be used at the eateries--Olives, Subway or The Axe and Palm.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review:
Cost: $12-14 for a great meal
Convenience: University Avenue, which has many great restaurants, is very close to campus and students without cars can ride there bikes there and have a great meal
Student Discounts: Pizza My Heart and other restaurants on University Avenue offer discounts for Stanford students..students recieve coupons at beginning of year for these places.
Variety: Eating in Palo Alto (off-campus) offers much variety like Indian, Thai, Japanese, Chinese, Greek, Singaporean, Brazilian, Italian...you name it. 
Best Places to Check Out: Osteria, Fuki Sushi, any of the gelato places on University Avenue, La Strada, Siam Royale (Thai), Pasta?, Peninsula Fountain & Grill, Taipan (Dim Sum)
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Mostly Too Expensive â€“ We are in downtown Palo Alto, one of the wealthiest cities in the US. Things are very expensive so it is hard to want to spend money in downtown. Most food places are affordable for special occasions. Transportation is fairly accessible and the bus system is great.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Okay but Could Be Better â€“ There seems to be a pattern that the closer you are to main campus the worse your food is. Sometimes the options are repetitive and tasteless. The houses however, seem to have far better food options. Flex dollar locations are expensive and we aren't alloted enough flex dollars.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Downtown Palo Alto â€“ The dining options in downtown Palo Alto (specifically on University Avenue) are great! There is a lot of variety, and you will find almost everything you are looking for. The pricing is kind of high for college students, but its a great place to go if you need to get some off campus food. My favorite places would be either California Pizza Kitchen or Bucca Di Peppo, they are both amazing places to go out and have a nice meal with friends or family!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Could Be Better â€“ Off-campus dining is pretty okay, but has a tendency of being a little out of the student price range. There are a couple of different places that offer delivery to dorms, pizza places especially. Also, there are plenty of fast food places for quick cheap meals though those are a little further away than the more legitimate restaurants.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Pretty Great â€“ There are plenty of dining halls at Stanford, and each have their own theme food style. There is always a dining hall serving food that you'll want to eat, though sometimes you might have to journey to the other side of campus to get to it. Also, there are flexible meal plan options that allow you to use your money at other food joints on campus. Those plans are great ways to have money to grab a quick lunch between classes when you don't have the time to make it back to the dining hall for a meal.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Wide Variety & Unique Aspects â€“ My local dorm's dining hall offers ice cream at every meal (due to conditions set forth by the woman who donated $1 million for the construction of the hall) in addition to an Indian-themed dinner on Sunday evenings.  Nevertheless, there is a wide variety of food available throughout campus, and students on the meal plan (including all Freshman) can eat at any dining facility.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Palo Alto, University Avenue â€“ Palo Alto is the nearest city to Stanford University. Easily accessable by free Stanford Shuttle or a long walk, there are lots of options that range in cost: Cheesecake Factory, Pizza My Heart, and more trendy and less heard of chains that are less expensive, and often offer a great range in regards to culture (from Thai to Italian). Palo Alto is small though, and after several occassion it may seem "same old, same old."
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Too Crowded! With over 1000 students, we are limited to only so much space during lunch. We can't pass certain areas during lunch so we are confined to only a little space either outside or in the cafeteria where the space is so small and crowded!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Great Organic Food, Lacks Variety â€“ All the food served at Stanford are organic, so they're pretty healthy. The dining halls serve pretty good food, though there isn't that much variety. A good way to combat this is by visiting different dinning halls every week. Occasionally, they will invite renown chefs over. These meals are AMAZING. Late-night dinning is also very helpful for those long study nights.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live in a quad and it is the best experience of my life.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I didn't really get a chance to see other dorms, but Stanford provides great housing. Buildings are clean and moderate. I don't feel cramped at all. Living spaces are clusters so there are always be another building with people, but spread out that you and your building have their own space.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Lived in Flomo my frosh year - was a fantastic experience!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The buildings are nice and comfortable, sometimes even the architecture and interior design in pretty.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I would say it's okay, but then I saw the situation at other schools.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Lots of options, clean and modern, range of social types
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Good options but off campus housing is very expensive
Housing.Author: College Freshman
